metadata.case_name: Seth Badri Prasad & Ors. v. Nagar Mal & Ors.

facts.text: Cloth control came into force in Rewa State; cloth dealers of Budhar formed Association of 25 members with initial capital of one lac rupees; no formal Articles of Association written nor registered.
Association functioned through President and pioneer worker who kept accounts and distributed profits.
Nagar Mal (respondent 1) was President from January 1946 to June 26, 1946; Seth Badri Prasad (one of plaintiffs-appellants) was President before and after.
Association worked till February 1948 when cloth was decontrolled and its work ended.

On June 25, 1949, thirteen members out of twenty-five brought suit alleging Nagar Mal gave accounts for Jan-Mar 1946 but not for Apr-Jun 1946; prayed for accounts from April 1946 to June 26, 1946, payment of dues with interest.

Real dispute related to sale of Gwalior consignment: 666 bales came in April 1946; Cloth Control Officer ordered allotment to Nagar Mal who would give Association option; ultimately 390 bales allotted to Association; Nagar Mal gave benefit of sales of 106 bales; dispute on profits from remaining 284 bales.

Additional District Judge, Umaria, passed preliminary decree on June 4, 1951 directing Nagar Mal to render accounts from April 1 to June 26, 1946, including profits on 390 bales (excluding 106) per capital shares.
Judicial Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, on November 20, 1951 reversed District Judge, held other members not entitled to profits on 284 bales, Nagar Mal rendered other accounts, dismissed suit.
Preliminary objection by respondent 1: suit not maintainable under s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 as Association of more than 20 persons not registered, illegal.
Appellants' counsel conceded s.4(2) was in force in Rewa State at formation and till 1950.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit for accounts is maintainable given the Cloth Association was formed by more than 20 persons without registration under s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act, 1935, rendering it illegal.
Whether preliminary objection under s.4(2) can be raised for the first time in Supreme Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: Preliminary objection should not be allowed at this late stage as not raised in courts below.
Even if in contravention of s.4(2), purpose not illegal; suit maintainable for recovery of contributions and accounts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu

petitioner_arguments.text: By analogy to s.69(3)(a) Indian Partnership Act, 1932, right to sue for accounts of dissolved firm.

respondent_arguments.text: Cloth Association illegal under s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act, 1935 as >20 persons for business acquiring gain, not registered; no remedy for contribution/apportionment in partnership dealings; suit for accounts not maintainable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act, 1935; Lindley on Partnership

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary objection raisable as pure question of law on public statute, prohibitory; no court can enforce invalid contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Objection rests on public statute; cannot be excluded even if raised late. Cites Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton; Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi.

court_reasoning.text: Association illegal; suit seeks enforcement of illegal contract by demanding accounts implying recognition of association; members have no remedy against each other for partnership transactions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court cannot assist in getting accounts of illegal association. Distinguishes U. Sein Po (sought refund of subscriptions, not enforcement). Cites Lindley on Partnership; Senaji Kapurchand v. Pannaji Devichand.

court_reasoning.text: Analogy to s.69(3)(a) Partnership Act inapplicable as unregistered firm not illegal, unlike here; suit not for dissolved firm but illegal association.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No compulsion to register partnership, but disabilities differ from illegality.

holdings.text: Preliminary objection succeeds; suit not maintainable as Association illegal under s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act, 1935; no relief for accounts of illegal partnership transactions.
Objection under prohibitory public statute can be raised at any stage, even first time in Supreme Court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Surajmull Nargoremull v. Triton Insurance Company Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Objection under prohibitory statute raisable late; no court enforces invalid contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Sri Shiba Prasad Singh v. Maharaja Srish Chandra Nandi
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot exclude public statute from consideration even if not argued below.

precedents_cited.case_name: U. Sein Po v. U. Phyu
precedents_cited.relevance: Allowed refund of subscriptions for illegal association but not enforcement of accounts.
No relief if contract illegal on face of plaint.
Same view on illegality barring suit.

statutes_cited.name: Rewa State Companies Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits association/partnership of >20 persons for gain without registration; renders Association illegal, barring suit for accounts.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy rejected; unregistered firm not illegal.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned in precedent but not directly applied.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar provision referenced in U. Sein Po case.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Stamp Act, 1899
statutes_cited.relevance: Cited in Surajmull precedent for late objection.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld preliminary objection, held Cloth Association illegal under s.4(2) Rewa State Companies Act, 1935; suit for accounts not maintainable; allowed appeal of respondent, dismissed plaintiffs' suit.

key_quotes.text: "No court can enforce as valid that which competent enactments have declared shall not be valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies allowing late preliminary objection under prohibitory statute.

key_quotes.text: The most important consequence... of illegality in a contract of partnership is that the members... have no remedy against each other for contribution or apportionment in respect of the partnership dealings.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle barring suit for accounts of illegal association.
